title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act is titled the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purposes. The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions and promote effective congressional oversight to ensure proper implementation of laws by the executive branch. Congress emphasizes the need for accurate information to make efficient, effective, and fair decisions. The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions and promote effective congressional oversight to ensure proper implementation of laws by the executive branch. The Act's purposes include increasing transparency, promoting effective oversight, and enhancing accountability of Congress and agencies to the people they serve. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "agency" refers to the definition in section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code. An "economically significant rule" includes any proposed or final rule with a significant economic impact or affecting various aspects of the economy. An "independent evaluation" involves a thorough assessment of data, methodology, and assumptions used by the agency and the public in developing economically significant rules. An "independent evaluation" involves a substantive assessment of an agency's and the public's data, methodology, and assumptions used in developing economically significant rules, including an explanation of strengths and weaknesses and their implications for the rulemaking. SEC. 4. REPORT ON RULES. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the rule to the relevant committees in Congress within specific timeframes. The Comptroller General must submit a report on an economically significant rule to Congress committees within specific timeframes, including an independent evaluation of the rule's potential benefits and costs. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress committees on an economically significant rule, evaluating its potential benefits, costs, alternative approaches, and regulatory impact analysis. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress committees on an economically significant rule, evaluating its potential benefits, costs, alternative approaches, and regulatory impact analysis. The report should include reasons why alternatives could not be adopted, an evaluation of the regulatory impact analysis, and a summary of the results of the evaluation by the Comptroller General. Procedures for determining the priority and number of requests will be developed in consultation with Senate and House leaders. The Comptroller General, in consultation with Senate and House leaders, will develop procedures to prioritize and report on requests for review of proposed rulemaking and interim final rulemaking. Agencies must cooperate promptly with the Comptroller General, and the Act does not expand or limit the authority of the General Accounting Office. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published 3 years after the effective date.
